Somehow the file MemoryEstimatorOracle.java wasn't committed. I pulled the most recent changes, I can see the commit log (see below), but this file is missing.

commit f5b685efa09b539b1f95925405723f7ac7b1dcea
Author: Hassan Eslami <heslami@apache.org>
Date:   Fri Dec 23 12:03:37 2016 -0600

    GIRAPH-1125

Igor, can you please explain what was broken? I don't see any description neither in jira ticket nor here

Added tests would be failing. 
When toQuit was passed true - no more pieces were executed within this block, i.e. toQuit was behaving as break in the loop after every piece, instead of being checked only when looping. Example:


```
ObjectHolder<Boolean> toQuit = new ObjectHolder<Boolean>();
RepeatUntilBlock.unlimited(
  new SequenceBlock(
    Pieces.masterCompute((master) -> toQuit.accept(true)),
    new Piece(),   <<-------- this piece wouldn't be executed, but should
  ),
  toQuit())
```
Do you have any tutorial for this?

I'm finding that roughly half of my ~2 hour job time is spent just loading the graph. Resuming from checkpoint lets me skip that step if something fails. This is also why I want to make sure that Giraph checkpoints before starting superstep 0. (It used to work this way, and it's documented in the Giraph book.)
Merged.
Can we get rid of getHostnamePartitionId() to avoid incorrectly using it in the future? I see various other places where taskPartition is used for identifier, do any of them need to be updated too?

There actually is [one instance][1] where I think it's okay to use `getHostnamePartitionId`. This happens in `BspServiceMaster.becomeMaster` when creating a master bid in ZK, before any `TaskInfo` instance is created.

This does make me realize, though, that I need to make the same change to how the task id is set in `BspServiceMaster`.

What about just changing how `taskPartition` is set in `BspService`, like so?

    this.taskPartition = (int)getApplicationAttempt() * conf.getMaxWorkers() + getTaskPartition();

I think this is actually the minimal code change to fix the issue. I don't see anywhere in the code that actually cares about the task partition as anything other than a unique identifier.

[1]: https://github.com/apache/giraph/blob/trunk/giraph-core/src/main/java/org/apache/giraph/master/BspServiceMaster.java#L805

This is ready for another look. I've replaced partition id with task id. The only place that actually needs a partition id is logging missing workers in `BspServiceMaster`. In that case, it's easy enough to recover the partition id by taking the task id modulo the number of workers.
Looks good to me.
As opposed to timestamps why not set the counters to the time passed between the different fractions? That's going to be easier to parse quickly.

Btw, did you squash the commits? You don't need to, they are squashed automatically when the pull request is merged. And we don't loose the diff between updates.

Looks good too me.

These columns correspond to the different variables in linear regression model and include the number of edges read so far, number of vertices computed etc. A case of an invalid column would be all samples have a value of zero for this column (e.g. there no vertices computed yet). Another case would be there is a linear dependency between two columns, so you can't run the regression.
In addition to standard tests, I run HelloPageRank application but explicitly throwing a DigraphDataException.

Good observation. Creating an OutEdges instance gets called a number of times in the order of the number of vertices. Now, this becomes an issue when the the creation of a new OutEdges instance does some expensive initialization, e.g. accessing parameters from the configuration can sometimes be expensive. With the factory, one can essentially cache this, upon the instantiation of the factory, and then pass the cached value to the OutEdges instance.

I've tried this with an application that does such an expensive operation adding mainly memory overhead, and the difference in performance is significant.
Are you not planning to implement caching as part of this check-in?
This is only introducing the factory that allows to do the caching, but how it's used for caching is application-specific, not part of this.
@majakabiljo Trying to understand the project structure, what are these stale pull requests about?
FindBugs is BSD, there's been some threads in other places indicating this is true based on the LICENSE file, but the maven package was built incorrectly.

I did come across this thread [1], which discusses that `com.google.code.findbugs:jsr305` is BSD, and documents that the JSR-305's BSD license is included in the findbugs repo [2].  But the license for FindBugs source is LGPL [3].

Unfortunately, Giraph is using `com.google.code.findbugs:annotations` which includes both JSR-305 and some FindBugs annotations [4], [5] which do have LGPL headers in the source listings.

[1] https://github.com/findbugsproject/findbugs/issues/128
[2] https://github.com/findbugsproject/findbugs/blob/2.0.2/findbugs/licenses/LICENSE-jsr305.txt
[3] https://github.com/findbugsproject/findbugs/blob/2.0.2/findbugs/licenses/LICENSE.txt
[4] https://github.com/findbugsproject/findbugs/blob/2.0.2/findbugs/src/java/edu/umd/cs/findbugs/annotations/SuppressFBWarnings.java
[5] https://github.com/findbugsproject/findbugs/blob/2.0.2/findbugs/src/java/edu/umd/cs/findbugs/annotations/SuppressWarnings.java
While we're at this, maybe we can upgrade Kryo as well? Our version is 3 years old. If so, let's do this separately.
Good point, I will upgrade the kryo version separately.

UnsafeByteArray streams now extends kryo Output/Input streams so that kryo serialization can directly write to this stream without using an additional buffer, providing a faster serialization.

Tests performed:
- Giraph unit tests
- Snapshot tests
- Run several workloads with different applications and measured correctness/performance, running time stayed in the boundary of the current values.
Why do we have to create ByteArrayVertexIdMessages before adding to MessageStore, would it be possible to fix that instead and then we get benefit on all apps?
A more general solution at https://github.com/apache/giraph/pull/72.

The custom class resolver allows kryo to always use the integer IDs for classes that are agreed by all nodes running the job. Default class resolver always writes the full class name of  the first encountered class type to the stream, and then it assigns an integer for subsequent instances. These changes make the serialization faster by eliminating the need to write the full name for the first encountered class instance. 

Tests:
1- Unit tests
2- Snapshot tests
3- Ran with two production pipelines
     Running time for mutual friends pipeline decreased from 41 to 35 minutes.

Can you comment on how this improves performance?
Can also describe why this change is necessary?

FileInputStream and FileOutputStream override the finalize method. As a result, their objects are only cleaned when the garbage collector performs a sweep. Since Java 7, programmers can use Files.newInputStream and Files.newOutputStream instead of FileInputStream and FileOutputStream to improve performance. finalize method is deprecated in Java 9+.

@aanchal204, did we try to reproduce this and verify the exception is caught?

Strings can be used to represent a file system path even though some classes are specifically designed for this task. For instance, java.nio.Path. It is useful to change the type of the variable to Path, since strings can be combined in an undisciplined way, which can lead to invalid paths. Second, different operating systems use different file separators, which can cause bugs.
Can you also add a couple of comments about how this was tested?

I used a pipeline which runs 100 jobs and was always getting at least a few jobs stuck with open network requests. Running it with more logging helped identify these two issues, and after the change it was 100% successful.

I tested that this exception was being thrown. 
Details:
 
  @Test
  public void testNegativeArraySizeException() {
    OutEdges<LongWritable, DoubleWritable> edges = instantiateOutEdges(ByteArrayEdges.class);
    System.out.println("Testing");
    try {
      for (int i = 0; i < 2000000000; i++) {
        edges.add(EdgeFactory.create(new LongWritable(i), new DoubleWritable(2.4)));
      }
    } catch (IllegalStateException e) {
      e.printStackTrace();
    }
    assertEquals(2000000000, edges.size());
  }
